key_facts: As of 2019, an estimated 9 million people get sick from typhoid and 110,000 people die from it every year.
Symptoms include prolonged fever, fatigue, headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea. Some patients may have a rash.
Severe cases may lead to serious complications or even death.
Typhoid fever can be treated with antibiotics, but increasing resistance to antibiotics is complicating treatment.
The typhoid conjugate vaccine is recommended for children from 6 months of age and adults up to 45 or 65 years (depending on the vaccine).
Two typhoid conjugate vaccines have been prequalified by WHO since 2017 and are being introduced into childhood immunization programs in typhoid-endemic countries.

overview.description: Typhoid fever is a life-threatening infection caused by the bacterium Salmonella Typhi, usually spread through contaminated food or water.
overview.transmission: Once Salmonella Typhi bacteria are ingested, they multiply and spread into the bloodstream.
overview.risk_factors: Urbanization, climate change, and antibiotic resistance can increase the global burden of typhoid, especially in communities lacking safe water or adequate sanitation.

symptoms.diagnosis: Typhoid fever can be confirmed through blood testing.

environment.risk_factors: Higher in populations lacking access to safe water and adequate sanitation, especially in children.
environment.vaccine_effectiveness: Vaccinated individuals have a lower risk and milder symptoms, while unvaccinated patients may experience more severe symptoms.
